Are there really any neutron stars visible to the naked eye? I doubt it. I mean, the white dwarf Sirius B is not visible to the naked eye but it probably would be once Sirius A dies. Neutron stars are much much smaller than white dwarves. While a white dwarf might be the size of earth, a neutron star is the size of a city.

Adaptive optics shows you as you "were" not "are" because when we look into space, we are looking into the past. For instance, if you see a star that is 100 light years away, you are seeing light that is being emitted by that star from 100 years ago. 👌🏼 For all we know, that star could be dead now and no longer emits any light. 6000 LY? Can we measure redshift over those distances? What if it is actually moving toward us?

P.S. the reentry corridor for a meteorite of that size and apparent density (3000 kg/m^3) not to explode into dust at high altitude is absolutely tiny. 1 degree or so at the minimum velocity it could have upon atmospheric entry.

On the other hand, the damage to the surroundings is, somewhat surprisingly, negligible. The meteorite would do hardly any damage to the surroundings, likely destroying the engine compartment and nothing else. The sound would be loud, but no fireball, blast wave, or shrapnel throwing would occur.

Twinkle Twinkle Little Star :)

Astronomically correct, yes. Too bad it's not grammatically correct. You need a "direct address" comma after 'Twinkle'. The correct phrasing is "Twinkle, twinkle, little star". And the direct address comma is not optional, though it's missing from much written speech nowadays. Look it up.

Remember, the direct address comma saves lives! "Let's eat grandma!" vs. "Let's eat, Grandma!"

What's the probability that a meteorite will land on your car?

Glad you asked. Meteorites of that size hit the Earth around 10 times a year, and are about 3 feet across, covering maybe 6 square feet of ground. The surface area of the Earth is about 5.48926e15 square feet, There is a 1.0930435e-13% chance of a one of those meteorites hitting any square foot of Earth, multiply that by ten and we have about a 1.093e-12% chance of a square foot of Earth being hit a year. If a car was squished to 2-d, the area of a mid-sized car would be 100 square feet. So we multiply our chance by 100 and we get...

There is a 1.093e-10% chance that a meteorite of that size will hit your car in a year (if it stays still).

Hi

I'm fairly certain the original still works.
"Twinkle, twinkle, little star," - stars do appear to twinkle
"How I wonder what you are" - nothing to say here
"Up above the world so high" - the world's been introduced as a frame of reference, so some stars are higher than it
"Like a diamond in the sky" - the simile makes sense
"Twinkle, twinkle, little star," - last two lines are repeats of the first two
"How I wonder what you are."

With that said, this is still a pretty cool song.

The meteorite that hit the car was not astronomically correct. Or not physically, at least. If it were that size, it wouldn't have landed on the hood, but vaporized the car into a huge crater. Twinkle, twinkle, little star,
how I wonder what you are.
Giant thermonuclear reaction,
held by gravitational attraction.
Twinkle, twinkle, little star,
you look so small cause you're so far.

As you burn through constant fusion,
your twinkle's just an optical illusion,
that happens when your light gets near,
distorted by our atmosphere.
Twinkle, twinkle, little star,
spreading light and heat so far.

As you use up fuel you'll grow,
and give off a scarlet glow.
Maybe you'll go supernova
exploding elements all over.
Now I know just what you are,
and I know I'm made of stars.
